title: 115_hr6380
content: The "Crowdfunding Amendments Act" may be cited as the short title. This Act introduces crowdfunding vehicles. The Securities Act of 1933 is amended to include the term 'crowdfunding vehicle' as defined in the Investment Company Act of 1940. Amendments are made to section 4(a)(6) regarding the sale of securities to investors, excluding crowdfunding vehicles. Amendments are made to the Investment Company Act of 1940 to include crowdfunding vehicles as a new category. This defines a crowdfunding vehicle as a company with a limited purpose outlined in its organizational documents. The company defined as a crowdfunding vehicle has a limited purpose of acquiring, holding, and disposing of securities issued by a single company. It issues only one class of securities, receives no compensation related to securities transactions, and prohibits any compensation based on capital gains for investment advisers or associated persons. The crowdfunding vehicle must meet certain criteria, including being current with reporting requirements and being advised by an investment adviser. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to require crowdfunding vehicles to be advised by a registered investment adviser who discloses fees to investors and obtains approval for fee increases. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to define 'crowdfunding vehicle' and 'crowdfunding vehicle adviser' as per specific criteria, without considering the activities of any affiliate of the investment adviser. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to require registration for crowdfunding vehicle advisers and allows tailored requirements for them. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to require registration for crowdfunding vehicle advisers and allows tailored requirements for them, including specific provisions related to subparagraphs and paragraphs. SEC. 3. CROWDFUNDING EXEMPTION FROM REGISTRATION. Section 12(g)(6) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to provide an unconditional exemption for securities offered by issuers with a public float of less than $75,000,000. The public float calculation is determined by multiplying the worldwide non-affiliate shares of common equity securities by the last sold price in the principal market. The exemption for securities offered by an issuer with annual revenues less than $50,000,000 is unconditional if the public float calculation is zero.
